Description: The 1st Precinct serves an area that consists of a square mile on the southernmost tip of Manhattan. The precinct is home to the World Trade Center, SOHO, Tribeca, and Wall Street.
The 5th Precinct serves the southeastern edge of Manhattan. The precinct is not only home to Chinatown, but also contains Little Italy, and the Bowery.

The 6th Precinct serves the southwestern Manhattan neighborhoods of Greenwich Village and the West Village. Some popular destinations in the precinct are Christopher Street, Washington Square Park, and Broadway.

The 7th Precinct serves Manhattan's Lower East Side. It is the second smallest precinct in the city consisting of only .62 square miles. The precinct is home to the Williamsburg Bridge and Orchard Street, which is transformed into an open-air mall every Sunday.
The 9th Precinct serves the area from East Houston Street to East 14 Street from Broadway, to the East River in Manhattan. The precinct is home to the East Village, and features Tompkins Square Park.

The 10th Precinct serves Chelsea, Clinton/Hell's Kitchen South and the Hudson Yards neighborhoods. The precinct is home to the Jacob Javits Convention Center, Chelsea Piers, Chinese Consulate, and the Fashion Institute of Technology.

The 13th Precinct serves a southern portion of Midtown, Manhattan. The precinct features the Peter Cooper Village/Stuyvesant Town residential complex, Gramercy Park, the lower portion of Rosehill, Madison Square Park, and Union Square Park.

As its name implies, the Midtown South Precinct serves the southern portion of Midtown, Manhattan. The area contains commercial offices, hotels, Times Square, Grand Central Terminal, Penn Station, Madison Square Garden, Koreatown section, and the Manhattan Mall Plaza.
The 17th Precinct serves the east side of Midtown, Manhattan. Some of the neighborhoods it covers are Sutton Area, Beekman Place, Kipps Bay, Turtle Bay, Murray Hill, and the Rose Hill Community.

The Midtown North Precinct serves the area of Midtown, Manhattan, just south of Central Park. The precinct encompasses the Diamond District, St. Patrick's Cathedral, the Theatre District, Restaurant Row, Radio City Music Hall, and Rockefeller Plaza.

The 19th Precinct command serves the Upper East Side of Manhattan. The precinct is one of the most densely populated residential areas in Manhattan. The southern part of the precinct has a large commercial area and features Madison, Lexington, and 3rd Avenues, which are well known for their shopping.

The 20th Precinct serves the Upper West Side of Manhattan. The precinct contains the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, the American Museum of Natural History, the New York Historical Society, the Beacon Theater, and the Jewish Community Center of Manhattan.

The Central Park Precinct patrols the park’s expansive 843 acres. Central Park is home to seven naturalistic water bodies, 58 miles of pedestrian paths, six miles of roads, almost five miles of bridle path, and approximately 20,000 trees. The park also offers 30 tennis courts, 26 ball fields, 21 playgrounds, two ice skating rinks, and a swimming pool.
The 23rd Precinct serves East Harlem, or El Barrio, north of East 96th Street. The Precinct is primarily a residential area, with some small commercial districts.

The 24th Precinct is located on the Upper West Side of Manhattan and encompasses Manhattan Valley and a portion of Riverside Park. It is a residential and commercial community of multiple dwelling homes and one major housing development.

The 25th Precinct encompasses the northern portion of East Harlem. The precinct is home to large residential community as well as Marcus Garvey Park, Harlem Art Park, and the 125th Street Metro-North Station.

The 26th Precinct services a portion of the Upper West Side of the Manhattan. The area covered encompasses Morningside Heights and Manhattanville, and is home to Columbia University, Riverside Park, Morningside Park, and General Grant National Memorial.
The 28th Precinct serves the central portion of Harlem. The precinct is home to the historic Apollo Theater, the Adam Clayton Powell Harlem State Office Building, and the Studio Museum in Harlem.

The 30th Precinct serves the western portion of Harlem. The neighborhoods covered by the precinct are Hamilton Heights, Sugar Hill, and West Harlem. The precinct contains Riverside Park and Jackie Robinson Park.

The 32nd Precinct serves the northeastern portion of Harlem. There are six public housing complexes and 11 private housing developments. The business district is located on Lenox Ave. between West 132nd and 139th Streets.
The 33rd Precinct serves the Washington Heights section of northern Manhattan. The three primary commercial strips are Broadway, Amsterdam and St. Nicholas Avenues.

The 34th Precinct serves the communities of Washington Heights and Inwood, north of West 179th Street. The precinct covers two square miles, with 500 acres of parkland, including Inwood Hill Park and Fort Tyron Park.
The 40th Precinct is the southernmost precinct in the borough of the Bronx. The precinct serves Port Morris, Mott Haven, and Melrose.
The 41st Precinct serves Hunts Point and Longwood. The precinct’s main shopping area is located on Southern Blvd. from Westchester Avenue to E. 163rd Street.
New York City's 42nd Precinct serves an area of 1.09 square miles, and is known as the Morrisania section of the Bronx. The precinct contains Claremont, Crotona Park East, and Crotona Park.
The 43rd Precinct serves the southeast section of the Bronx. There are four primary commercial strips in the precinct: Westchester Avenue, Castle Hill Avenue, White Plains Road, and Parkchester.
The 44th Precinct serves 1.97 square miles of the southwest portion of the Bronx: The precinct is home to the Grand Concourse, Bronx Terminal Market, and Yankee Stadium.

The 45th Precinct serves a portion of the northeastern section of the Bronx. The precinct area contains six miles of park area, and 10.6 miles of waterfront. The precinct encompasses Co-op City and City Island.
The 46th Precinct serves the central part of the western Bronx. The precinct contains the Fordham, University Heights, Morris Heights and Mount Hope neighborhoods.
The 47th Precinct serves northern portion of the Bronx. Woodlawn, Wakefield, Williamsbridge, Baychester, Edenwald, Olinville, Fishbay, and Woodlawn Cemetary all call the precinct home.

The 48th Precinct sits in the heart of the Bronx, encompassing Belmont, East Tremont, and West Farms. Fordham University's Bronx campus is nestled in the precinct’s northern corner, the famous Arthur Avenue runs down the center, and the Cross Bronx Expressway and Crotona Park form the southern border.
The 49th Precinct serves a northeastern portion of the Bronx including Allerton, Morris Park, Van Nest, Pelham Parkway, Eastchester Gardens, and Pelham Gardens.

The 50th Precinct serves a northwestern region in the Bronx. The precinct is home to Riverdale, Fieldston, Kingsbridge, Marble Hill, and Spuyten Duyvil. Its many areas of interest include Wave Hill, a historic mansion and garden overlooking the Hudson River, and Van Cortlandt Park, one of the largest parks in New York City.
The 52nd Precinct serves a northern portion of the Bronx. The precinct is home to Bedford Park, Fordham, Kingsbridge, Norwood, Bronx Park, and University Heights.
The 60th Precinct serves the southernmost point of Brooklyn. The precinct covers 3.4 square miles of Brooklyn, and includes Coney Island, Brighton Beach, West Brighton Beach, and Sea Gate.
The 61st Precinct serves a southern portion of Brooklyn and encompasses Kings Bay, Gravesend, Sheepshead Bay, and Manhattan Beach.
The 62 Precinct serves a southwestern portion of Brooklyn. The precinct is home to Bensonhurst, Mapleton, and Bath Beach.

The 63rd Precinct serves approximately 8.96 square miles and features 1.5 square miles of park. In addition, this command also includes undeveloped marshlands of the Marine Park area. The precinct borders a national park, the Gateway National Recreation Area.

The 66th Precinct serves the Borough Park section of Brooklyn, including Midwood and Kensington. It features over 300 religious institutions, comprised mostly of Hassidic and Orthodox Synagogues and Yeshivas.
The 67th Precinct serves a region in the center of Brooklyn, comprising East Flatbush and Remsen Village.
The 68th Precinct serves a southwestern portion of Brooklyn, and includes Bay Ridge and Dyker Heights.
The 69th Precinct serves the Canarsie section of Brooklyn. The precinct is mostly residential with commercial strips along Avenue L, Rockaway Parkway, and Remsen Avenue.
The 70th Precinct is centrally located in the borough of Brooklyn. This precinct is home to Midwood, Fiske Terrace, Ditmas Park, and Prospect Park South.
The 71st Precinct is located in central Brooklyn, and contains the southern portion of Crown Heights, Wingate, and Prospect Lefferts.
The 72nd Precinct serves a northwestern portion of Brooklyn that includes Sunset Park and Windsor Terrace.
The 73rd Precinct serves a northeastern area of Brooklyn containing Brownsville and Ocean Hill.
The 75th Precinct serves the easternmost portion of Brooklyn and envelopes East New York and Cypress Hills.
The 76th Precinct serves south Brooklyn, and includes the neighborhoods of Carroll Gardens, Red Hook, Cobble Hill, parts of Gowanus, and the Columbia Street Waterfront District.
The 77th Precinct serves the northern portion of the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn. The precinct is also home to a portion of Prospect Heights.
The 78 Precinct serves the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, and contains Prospect Park.
The 79th Precinct serves a northern portion of Brooklyn that includes Bedford Stuyvesant and features Herbert Von King Park.
The 81st Precinct serves a northern area in Brooklyn, containing Bedford Stuyvesent and Stuyvesant Heights.
The 83rd Precinct serves a northern region in Brooklyn comprising Bushwick.
The 84th Precinct serves a northwestern section of Brooklyn. The precinct is home to Brooklyn Heights, Boerum Hill, and Vinegar Hill.
The 88th Precinct serves a northern portion of Brooklyn containing Clinton Hill, Fort Green Park, and Commodore Barry Park.
The 90th Precinct serves the northwestern portion of Brooklyn that mainly consists of the neighborhood of Williamsburg.
The 94th Precinct serves the northernmost portion of Brooklyn, consisting of, primarily, the neighborhood of Greenpoint.

The 100th Precinct serves a southern portion of Queens on the Rockaway Peninsula, and contains Arverne, Belle Harbor, Breezy Point, Broad Channel, Neponsit, Rockaway Park, Rockaway Beach, and Roxbury.
The 101st Precinct is located at the eastern end of the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens, and houses Far Rockaway and Bayswater.
The 102nd Precinct serves a portion of central Queens containing Kew Gardens, Richmond Hill East, Richmond Hill, Woodhaven, and the northern part of Ozone Park.
The 103rd Precinct serves a western portion of Queens, home to the downtown Jamaica Business District, Hollis Park Gardens, Hollis, Lakewood, and Jamaica.
The 104th Precinct serves the western section of Queens, containing Ridgewood, Glendale, Middle Village, and Maspeth.

The 105th Precinct serves the easternmost portion of Queens. Queens Village, Cambria Heights, Laurelton, Rosedale, Springfield Gardens, Bellerose, Glen Oaks, New Hyde Park, and Floral Park comprise the area covered by the precinct.
The 106th Precinct serves South Central Queens, and includes Ozone Park, South Ozone Park, Lindenwood, Howard Beach, and Old Howard Beach.
The 107th Precinct serves a portion of Northern Queens, containing Fresh Meadows, Cunningham Heights, and Hilltop Village.
The 108th Precinct serves the southwestern portion of Queens, and includes Long Island City, Sunnyside, and Woodside.
The 109th Precinct serves a north east portion of Queens, including Downtown Flushing, East Flushing, Queensboro Hill, College Point, Malba, Whitestone, Beechhurst, and Bay Terrace.

The 110th Precinct is located in the northern part of Queens. It encompasses the communities of Corona and Elmhurst. The precinct is mainly a residential/commercial community consisting of multiple dwelling homes, and one major apartment complex, Lefrak City. There are three major commercial districts in the command: Roosevelt Avenue, Broadway, and Queens Blvd.
The 111th Precinct serves a northeastern portion of Queens containing Bayside, Douglaston, Little Neck, Auburndale, Hollis Hills, and Fresh Meadows.
The 112th Precinct serves a centrally located portion of Queens, housing Forest Hills and Rego Park.
The 113th Precinct serves the southeastern area of Jamaica, Queens, along with St. Albans, Hollis, Springfield Gardens, South Ozone Park, South Jamaica, Addisleigh Park, and Locust Manor.
The 114th Precinct is located in the northwestern portion of Queens, and covers Astoria, Long Island City, Woodside, and Jackson Heights.
The 115th Precinct serves a northern portion of Queens, encompassing Jackson Heights, East Elmhurst, and North Corona. The precinct patrol responsibilities also include LaGuardia Airport.

The 120th Precinct serves the North Shore of Staten Island. The precinct is home to Castleton Corners, Westerleigh, Meiers Corners, Markham Gardens, Fort Wadsworth, Tompkinsville, Concord, Sunnyside, West Brighton, Livingston, Randall Manor, New Brighton, St. George, Ward Hill, Stapleton, Clifton, Silver Lake, Grymes Hill, Fox Hills, Shore Acres, and Rosebank.
The 121st Precinct serves the northwestern shore of Staten Island, containing Willowbrook, Westerleigh, Port Richmond, Mariner's Harbor, Elm Park, Port Ivory, Chelsea, and Bloomfield.

The 122nd Precinct serves a portion of the South Shore of Staten Island, which encompasses Eltingville, Great Kills, Bay Terrace, Oakwood Heights, Oakwood Beach, Lighthouse Hill, New Dorp, Grant City, Midland Beach, South Beach, Todt Hill, South Beach, Old Town, and Grasmere.
The 123rd Precinct serves a portion of the South Shore of Staten Island, including Tottenville, Huguenot, Rossville, Annadale, and Eltingville.
